t:t.t:p: Guessing the location of aqueen is often a crucialchallenge in the play of ahand. But while it's truethat an out-and-out guess isoccasionally unavoidable, aresourceful declarer canfrequently compel theopponents to solve theproblem for him.

For example, take this casewhere West led the king ofhearts against three notrump.South ducked, of course,hoping the suit would becontinued. Had West obliged,declarer would have scorednine easy tricks afterdriving out the ace ofdiamonds.

But West shifted to the clubqueen instead. Nine trickswere now still available,provided South could guesswhich way to take the two-wayspade finesse. There was noneed to try to solve thisproblem at once, though, sodeclarer decided to gatherall the information he couldto help find the winningsolution.

He began by also allowing thequeen of clubs to hold thetrick. When West thencontinued with the jack,declarer took his ace andplayed the king of diamonds.West won and returned theclub ten to dummy's king,East discarding a spade.
The Q-J of diamonds were nextcashed, West discarding aheart. At this point, seventricks had been played, andSouth had all the informationhe needed to assure thecontract.

At trick eight, the seven ofclubs was led, forcing Westto win with the eight asSouth discarded his lastdiamond. West then foundhimself in a losing position:Since he was out of diamondsand clubs, he had to return aheart or a spade.
A heart return into South'sA-J would hand him his ninthtrick, while a spade returnwould solve the problem inthat suit. Either way, threenotrump was now cold.
By developing an end positionthat allowed his opponents noescape, South eliminated allguesswork and so assured afavorable outcome.
